critique: The document reflects President Roosevelt's approval of an agreement within the construction industry under the National Industrial Recovery Act (NIRA) of 1933. It emphasizes compliance with the Code of Fair Competition for the Construction Industry. The NIRA was a key component of the New Deal, which sought to address the Great Depression through government intervention in the economy. The agreement pertains to employers and employees in the Electrical Contracting Division in Detroit, Michigan, and its metropolitan district. The document highlights the role of the National Industrial Recovery Board in analyzing and recommending the agreement for approval, indicating a structured, top-down approach to economic recovery.
